(22531360049) (cropped).jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 9 November 1850 | birth_place = [[Chester]] | death_date = 8 February 1936 | death_place = [[Malvern, Worcestershire|Malvern]] | death_cause = | residence = | other_names = | known_for = Philosophy | education = [[St John's College, Cambridge]] | employer = | occupation = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = | nationality = [[United Kingdom]] }} '''Alfred Caldecott''' (/ˈkɔːldəˌkɑːt/; 9 November 1850 – 8 February 1936) was an English philosopher.
==Early life== Caldecott was born at Challoner House, Crook Street, Chester. His father, John Caldecott, was an accountant, twice married with 13 children. Caldecott was his sixth child by his first wife Mary Dinah (née Brookes). His older brother [[Randolph Caldecott|Randolph]] was a renowned English artist and illustrator. In 1860 the family moved to 23 Richmond Place at Boughton just outside Chester. He spent the last five years of his schooling at The King's School, Chester.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Grayling|first1=A.C.|title=Continuum Companion of British Philosophy|date=2010|publisher=Continuum|isbn=9780199754694|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/viewbydoi/10.1093/acref/9780199754694.013.0343}}</ref>
In 1876 Caldecott went to [[St John's College, Cambridge]] to read the Moral Sciences Tripos and he took First Class honours in 1880. He was then elected to a Fellowship at St John's. He was one of the founders of the Cambridge University [[Moral Sciences Club]] and the first meeting took place on 19 October 1878 in his rooms at [[St John's College, Cambridge|St John's]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pitt|first1=Jack|title=Russell and the Cambridge Moral Sciences Club|journal=Russell|date=1981|volume=1|issue=2|pages=103–118}}</ref>
==Career== [[File:Elizabeth and Louisa Garrett Anderson, Alfred Caldecott and another, c.1910. (22531360049).jpg|thumb|[[Elizabeth Garrett Anderson|Elizabeth]] and [[Louisa Garrett Anderson]] and Alfred Caldecott on the day they went to see the Prime Minister]] After gaining his degree, Caldecott was elected to a Fellowship at St John's. He then took Holy Orders and became rector of North and South Topham in Norfolk from 1895-98. He joined [[King's College London]] in 1891 first as Chair of Logic and Mental Philosophy, then later as Chair of Mental and Moral Philosophy. He developed a syllabus with a renewed emphasis on theological issues.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Campbell|first1=Michael|last2=Johnson|first2=Andrew|last3=Papineau|first3=David|title=Philosophy at King’s College London – a History|url=https://www.kcl.ac.uk/artshums/depts/philosophy/about/historyphilosophy.pdf|accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref> He was Dean of King's College from 1913–17; and Prebendary of St Paul's from 1915 to 1935.
Caldecott wrote several books on religious subjects including: ''English Colonialism and the Empire'' (1891)and ''The Philosophy of Religion in England and America'' (1901). He also collaborated with his brother Randolph on one book: ''Aesop's Fables'' (1883).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Caldecott|first1=Randolph|title=Aesop's Fables|date=1883|publisher=Macmillan|url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/007696266}}</ref> The book contained his translation of Aesop from the original Greek.
In 1910 he made up a deputation with [[Elizabeth Garrett Anderson]] and [[Louisa Garrett Anderson]] who were allowed to put forward the case, for women to have the vote, to the Prime Minister.
He died on 8 February 1936, aged 85, at Malvern.
A portrait of Alfred painted by his brother Randolph Caldecott hangs in the Liverpool Academy of Arts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Liverpool Academy of Arts|url=http://www.la-art.co.uk|accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref>

Usti n / Labem).</ref> The altar wings exhibited at the Hussite Museum in Tabor have the status of a national cultural monument. These are the two sides painted plates accrued before 1486.<ref name=":0">''Horníčková K.'' Mezi tradicí a inovací.</ref> The wings were cut back and secondarily coated with baroque marbling, making reconversion survived the 17th and 18th centuries, since the inside of the right wing is the oldest depiction of the burning of [[Jan Hus]] depicted in the Czech Gothic panel painting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/arts/the-art-of-the-bohemian-reformation-turns-spotlight-on-lesser-known-period-of-art|title=Radio Prague -|website=www.radio.cz|access-date=2016-05-06}}</ref> It is believed to be a fragment of an [[altarpiece]], which has not survived. The anonymous painter portrayed "Crucifixion" and "The Last Supper", possibly in monstrance with the body of the Lord.<ref name=":1">''Royt, J.'' In: ''Gotické deskové malířství v severozápadních a severních Čechách 1340-1550'' (J. Royt, ed.</ref> Due to the fact that both wing plates are shown, it is assumed that the patron was [[Jakoubek of Vřesovice]], a Hussite captain, from Roudníky and his son John.<ref name=":1"/>
== Description == Each of the truncated wing plates has dimensions of 162 x 68 cm, framed 179 x 82 cm. The inner side of the left wing appears at the top of the ''Beheading of [[James, son of Zebedee|St. James the Greater]]'', while at the bottom is shown the Burning of [[Lawrence of Rome|St. Lawrence]]. The ''Beheading of St. James'' depicts two figures in discussion, one of which with a headdress in brocade in the form of a miter, the high priest [[Abiathar]]. The figure is a reference to the prelates who Hus condemned. In the lower part shows the ''death of St. Lawrence'', while the figure on the right is identifiable with the [[Decius|Emperor Decius]]. On the outer side of the plate is left St. James the Greater pilgrim's staff and St. Lawrence deacon holding the book and palm branch. Contralateral altar wing (board 2 inv. No. 4336) has on the inside at the top of ''Passion of Sebastian'', in the lower half of the burning of Jan Hus. On the outside is depicted [[James the Less|St. James the Less]], at the bottom of [[Saint Stephen|St. Stephen]] deacon. While the martyrdom of St. Sebastian depicts the [[Diocletian|Emperor Diocletian]] (left figure with a crown on his head), the "Burning" is dominated by the figure of a man with a princely cap. This represents Rhine Louis of Wittelsbach, which Sigismund handed Hus over to death. On the altar, cover it and Jan Hus assigned to prvomučedníkům Christian church – St. James, Vol. Sebastian and St. Lawrence. The fact that the left bottom plate is shown "baking" St. Lawrence, while on the right wing is depicted the "burning of Jan Hus", is not accidental. These are parallels between the forms of martyrdom of the saints.<ref name=":0"/>
== Dating == The altar wings are not dated nor signed. The time of their creation can be inferred either by comparing to the manuscript painters in contemporary context, or biographical content of the patron of the altar. Jaromir Pešina states that the author of the piece was in contact with [[St. George's altar]], whose work dates to early in the second half of the 15th century, newly assigned to Czech [[International Gothic|late Gothic]] panel painting.<ref>Pešina J. ''Desková malba''.</ref> Milena Bartlová considered the painter as a member of the Prague workshop environment with knowledge of the [[Nuremberg masters]] ([[Hans Pleydenwurff]]) and Brussels patterns ([[Dirck Bouts]]).<ref>Bartlová M. ''Upálení sv.''</ref> Jan Royt states that the artist who painted panels was aware of the [[Wrocław Master]] painting in the [[altar of St. Barbara]],<ref>Dobrzeniecki T. ''A Central Panel of a Pentaptych (The legend of S. Barbara)''.</ref> which could be instrumental in these Western European influences. These conjectures allow dating the genesis of the retable in 1470 to 1480s. In the event that the purchaser of the altar was a Hussite captain Jakoubek of Vřesovice, who died in 1467, dating emergence retable it can be shifted to the 1460s. [[The Church of St. Wenceslas (Roudníky)]], for whose altar it was intended, is already mentioned as a parish in 1352, and was rebuilt in the [[Gothic style]] in 1486.
== The wings' fate == In 1966, during restoration of the village church, students of the [[Academy of Fine Arts, Prague]] discovered two door panels on which were concealed, beneath overpainting, a baroque quality pre-medieval painting dating to the 1470s. Restoration of the original painted panels was done by Bohuslav and Ludmila Slaný in 1975. The last conservation and restoration work on both boards conducted by academic painter Naděžda Mašková and Miroslav Křížek in the year 2013/14. The altar wings were bought from the [[Trmice parish]] in the [[Diocese of Litomerice]] for the amount of CZK 12 million paid from the funds of the [[Ministry of Culture]] of the [[Czech Republic]]. Today it is one of the most important artistic artefacts, in the [[Hussite Museum]] in [[Tábor]].
== Art-historical importance == The finding of altar wings of Roudniky became one of the few documented [[Utraquist]] works in the development of painting in [[Bohemia]] after a period of stagnation on topics and painting techniques at the time of [[George of Poděbrady]]. It was a diversion in Prague acting "Master of St. George's altar" from a conservative home environment{{huh?|date=July 2018|reason=Seems to be mistranslated - the context is totally inappropriate for this phrase to make sense}} and the influence of Nuremberg painting from the mid-15th century, which influenced the anonymous Master. The Roudniky panels also likely originate from the Prague workshop environment.
The meaning of the altar wings of Roudniky lies in their [[iconography]]. Illustrations of Jan Hus as a holy martyr are captured in their oldest form, as we know from the few surviving fragments of altars from the middle of the 15th century.<ref name=":1"/> This monumental painting presents us with Jan Hus as a man of small stature with a round face, beardless, dressed in a liturgical white shirt. His representation with other religious saints assigns him to providence, and the founding legitimacy of the early church. Utraquists needed to present their own saint, with the traditional saints, as one of the reasons their relationship to the paintings had religious themes.<ref name=":0"/> Conversely the painting served as a means of spreading reform ideas, but had a didactic function for laymen unfamiliar with iconography.<ref>Studničková, M. ''Kališnická ikonografie a dobová zpodobnění M. Jana Husa''.</ref>
== Exhibitions == The altar wings of Roudniky was exhibited in the Teresian Wing of the Old Royal Palace at [[Prague Castle]] in the exhibition "[[Jan Hus]] 1415–2005" (30 June – 25 September 2005). Again, the two boards exhibited in the Imperial Stables at Prague Castle during the exhibition "Art of the Czech Reformation", which took place from 16 December 2009 to 4 April 2010. The new acquisition exhibiting an altar wing of the Hussite Museum in Tabor in February 2009, which is got into professional care at the end of 2012. the last two altar slabs enriched the exhibition "Prague Hus and the Hussite 1415–2015", which was held in the [[Clam-Gallas Palace]] in Prague from 25 September 2015 and 24 January 2016.

'''''An Essay on Liberation''''' is a 1969 book by the [[Frankfurt School]] philosopher [[Herbert Marcuse]].
==Summary== Marcuse argues that advanced industrial society has rendered the traditional conception of human freedom obsolete, and outlines new possibilities for contemporary human liberation.
==Reception== Brian Easlea writes that Marcuse, having in the past been attacked by Marxists for his "quite unambiguous indictment of science and perhaps feeling that he had directed too much attention away from the rulers of advanced industrial society", apparently "reversed direction" in ''An Essay on Liberation'' by endorsing science and technology as "great vehicles of liberation".<ref>{{cite book |author=Easlea, Brian |title=Science and Sexual Oppression: Patriarchy's Confrontation with Woman and Nature |publisher=Weidenfeld and Nicolson |location=London |year=1981 |page=25 |isbn=0 297 77894 3}}</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{context|date=September 2018}} {{technical|date=September 2018}} {{unfocused|date=September 2018}} }} '''Constructive theology''' is the redefinition or reconceptualization of what historically has been known as [[systematic theology]]. The reason for this reevaluation stems from the idea that, in systematic theology, the [[Christian theology|theologian]] attempts to develop a coherent theory running through the various doctrines within the tradition ([[Christology]], [[eschatology]], [[Pneumatology (Christianity)|pneumatology]], etc.). A potential problem underlying such study is that in constructing a system of theology, certain elements may be "forced" into a presupposed structure, or left out altogether, in order to maintain the coherence of the overall system.
In response to this realization, some modern theologians, especially [[Christian feminists]] such as [[Sallie McFague]], [[Catherine Keller (theologian)|Catherine Keller]], and Sharon V. Betcher, feel that the term "systematic" is no longer accurate in reference to theology, and prefer the language of constructive theology. While not a proponent of the language of 'constructive theology,' [[Karl Barth]] frequently criticized the practice of systematizing theology or structuring a coherent system upon a philosophical foundation external to theology's own internal commitments.
''Constructive Theology'' is also the title of a journal on the subject. A Bloomsbury book series on constructive theology, titled ''Rethinking Theologies, Constructing Alternatives'', is edited by Marion Grau, Susannah Cornwall, Steed Davidson and Hyo-Dong Lee.

{{About|the mental state}} {{Multiple issues| {{weasel|date=November 2008}} {{refimprove|date=September 2007}} {{original research|date=September 2007}} }} {{Certainty}} '''Doubt''' is a [[mental state]] in which the [[mind]] remains suspended between two or more contradictory propositions, unable to assent to any of them.{{Cite news | first = Alfred | last = Sharpe | authorlink = | author = | coauthors = | title = Doubt | url = http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/05141a.htm | agency = | work = The Catholic Encyclopedia |volume= Vol. 5 | publisher = Robert Appleton | location = New York | id = | pages = | page = | date = | accessdate = 2008-10-21 | quote = A state in which the mind is suspended between two contradictory propositions and unable to assent to either of them. }} {{bettersource|date=November 2017}} Doubt on an [[emotion]]al level is indecision between [[belief]] and [[wikt:disbelief|disbelief]]. It may involve [[uncertainty]], [[distrust]] or lack of conviction on certain [[fact]]s, actions, motives, or [[Decision making|decisions]]. Doubt can result in delaying or rejecting relevant action out of concern for mistakes or missed opportunities. [[File:Mr Pipo Think 03.svg|thumbnail|Doubt]] ==Definition== The concept of doubt as a suspense between two contradictory propositions covers a range of phenomena: on a level of the mind it involves reasoning, examination of facts and evidence and on an emotional level believing and disbelieving In premodern theology doubt was "the voice of an uncertain conscience" and important to realize, because when in doubt "the safer way is not to act at all". ==Impact on society== Doubt sometimes tends to call on [[reason]]. Doubt may encourage people to [[procrastination|hesitate]] before acting, and/or to apply more [[rigour|rigorous]] methods. Doubt may have particular importance as leading towards disbelief or non-acceptance. [[Politics]], [[ethics]] and [[law]], with decisions that often determine the course of individual [[personal life|life]], place great importance on doubt, and often foster elaborate [[adversarial process]]es to carefully sort through all available evidence. Societally, doubt creates an atmosphere of distrust, being accusatory in nature and ''de facto'' alleging either foolishness or deceit on the part of another. Such a stance has been fostered in Western European society since the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]], in opposition to [[tradition]] and [[authority]]. ==Psychology== [[Sigmund Freud]]'s [[psychoanalytic theory]] attributes doubt (which may be interpreted as a symptom of a [[phobia]] emanating from the [[Id, ego and super-ego|ego]]) to [[childhood]], when the ego develops. Childhood experiences, these theories maintain, can plant doubt about one's abilities and even about one's very [[Personal identity|identity]]. [[Cognitive]] mental as well as more [[spirituality|spiritual]] approaches abound in response to the wide variety of potential causes for doubt. [[Behavioral therapy]] — in which a person systematically asks his own [[mind]] if the doubt has any real basis — uses rational, [[Socratic method]]s. This method contrasts to those of say, the [[Buddhist]] faith, which involve a more [[esoteric]] approach to doubt and inaction. Buddhism sees doubt as a negative attachment to one's perceived [[past]] and [[future]]. To let go of the personal [[history]] of one's life (affirming this release every day in [[meditation]]) plays a central role in releasing the doubts — developed in and attached to — that history. Partial or intermittent negative [[reinforcement]] can create an effective [[climate of fear]] and doubt.{{Cite book|title=Who's Pulling Your Strings ? How to Break The Cycle of Manipulation |first=Harriet B.|last=Braiker |year=2004 |isbn=0-07-144672-9}} ==Philosophy== [[René Descartes|Descartes]] employed [[Cartesian doubt]] as a pre-eminent methodological tool in his fundamental philosophical investigations. Branches of philosophy like [[logic]] devote much effort to distinguish the dubious, the [[probability|probable]] and the certain. Much of illogic rests on dubious assumptions, dubious data or dubious conclusions, with [[rhetoric]], [[whitewash (censorship)|whitewashing]], and [[deception]] playing their accustomed roles. ==Theology== [[File:Caravaggio - The Incredulity of Saint Thomas.jpg|thumb|left|180px|''[[Doubting Thomas|The Incredulity of Saint Thomas]]'' by [[Caravaggio]].]] Doubt that god(s) exist may form the basis of [[agnosticism]] — the belief that one cannot determine the existence or non-existence of god(s). It may also form other brands of [[skepticism]], such as [[Pyrrhonism]], which do not take a positive stance in regard to the existence of god(s), but remain negative. Alternatively, doubt over the existence of god(s) may lead to acceptance of a particular religion: compare [[Pascal's Wager]]. Doubt of a specific theology, scriptural or deistic, may bring into question the truth of that theology's set of beliefs. On the other hand, doubt as to some doctrines but acceptance of others may lead to the growth of [[heresy]] and/or the splitting off of [[sect]]s or groups of thought. Thus [[proto-Protestantism|proto-Protestants]] doubted [[papal authority]], and substituted alternative methods of governance in their new (but still recognizably similar) churches. [[Christianity]] often debates doubt in the contexts of [[salvation]] and eventual redemption in an [[afterlife]]. This issue has become particularly important in [[Protestantism]], which requires ''only'' the acceptance of [[Jesus]], though more contemporary versions have arisen within the Protestant churches that resemble [[Catholicism]]. [[File:Rae, Henrietta - Doubts - 1886.jpg|thumb|180px|''Doubts'', by [[Henrietta Rae]], 1886]] Doubt as a path towards (deeper) [[belief]] lies at the heart of the story of Saint [[Thomas the Apostle]]. Note in this respect the theological views of [[Georg Hermes]]:
... the starting-point and chief principle of every science, and hence of theology also, is not only methodical doubt, but positive doubt. One can believe only what one has perceived to be true from reasonable grounds, and consequently one must have the courage to continue doubting until one has found reliable grounds to satisfy the reason. {{cite encyclopedia | last = Schulte | first = Karl Joseph | editor = | encyclopedia =The Catholic Encyclopedia | title = George Hermes | url = http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/07276c.htm | accessdate = 2008-10-21 | edition = | date = | year = 1910 | month = | publisher = Robert Appleton | volume = 7 | location = New York | id = | isbn = | doi = | pages = | quote = }}
[[Christian existentialism|Christian existentialists]] such as [[Søren Kierkegaard]] suggest that for one to truly have belief in God, one would also have to doubt one's beliefs about God; the doubt is the rational part of a person's thought involved in weighing evidence, without which the belief would have no real substance. Belief is not a decision based on evidence that, say, certain beliefs about God are true or a certain person is worthy of love. No such evidence could ever be enough to pragmatically justify the kind of total commitment involved in true theological belief or romantic love. Belief involves making that commitment anyway. Kierkegaard thought that to have belief is at the same time to have doubt.''Concluding Unscientific Postscript to Philosophical Fragments'', ed. by Howard V. Hong and Edna H. Hong, v. 1, Princeton University Press, 1992, pp. 21–57''Soren Kierkegaard's Journals and Papers'', trans. Hong and Malantschuk, p. 399. ==Law== Most [[criminal law|criminal]] cases within an [[adversarial system]] require that the prosecution proves its contentions [[beyond a reasonable doubt]] — a doctrine also called the "[[Legal burden of proof|burden of proof]]". This means that the State must present propositions which preclude "reasonable doubt" in the mind of a [[reasonable person]] as to the guilt of defendant. Some doubt may persist, but only to the extent that it would ''not'' affect a "reasonable person's" belief in the defendant's guilt. If the doubt raised ''does'' affect a "reasonable person's" belief, the jury is not satisfied beyond a "reasonable doubt". The [[jurisprudence]] of the applicable jurisdiction usually defines the precise meaning of words such as "reasonable" and "doubt" for such purposes. ==Science==
To doubt everything or to believe everything are two equally convenient solutions; both dispense with the necessity of reflection. —[[Henri Poincaré]], Science and Hypothesis (1905) (from Dover abridged edition of 1952)
The [[scientific method]] regularly quantifies doubt, and uses it to determine whether [[further research is needed]]. [[Isaac Azimov]], in his essay collection ''[[Fact and Fancy]]'', described science as a system for causing and resolving intelligent doubt.http://patduffyhutcheon.com/humanist%20articles/asimov.htm ==See also== * [[Doubting Thomas]] * [[Fear, uncertainty and doubt]] * [[Further research is needed]] * [[List of ethics topics]] * [[Methodic doubt]] * [[Philosophical skepticism]] * [[Question]] * [[Reasonable doubt]] * [[Skepticism]] ==Notes and references== {{Wikiquote}} {{Wiktionary|doubt|dubious}} {{Commons category|Doubt}} {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * [[Peter L. Berger|Berger, Peter L.]] and Zijderveld, Anton (2009). ''In Praise of Doubt: How to Have Convictions Without Becoming a Fanatic''. New York: HarperOne. {{ISBN|978-0-06-177816-2}}. A book by two eminent sociologists, one American and the other Dutch. * {{Cite book |last=Hecht |first=Jennifer Michael |authorlink=Jennifer Michael Hecht |title=Doubt: a history: the great doubters and their legacy of innovation from Socrates and Jesus to Thomas Jefferson and Emily Dickinson |year= 2003 |month= |publisher= HarperSanFrancisco |location= San Francisco |isbn= 0-06-009795-7 }} This book traces the role of doubt through human history, all over the world, particularly regarding religion. * Hein, David (Winter 2006). The '''''{{lang|la|Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium}}''''' ([[Latin language|Latin]] for "Moral Letters to [[Lucilius Junior|Lucilius]]"), also known as the '''''Moral Epistles''''', is a collection of 124 letters which were written by [[Seneca the Younger]] at the end of his life, during his retirement, and written after he had worked for the Emperor [[Nero]] for more than ten years. They are addressed to [[Lucilius Junior|Lucilius]], the then [[Procurator (Roman)|procurator]] of [[Sicilia (Roman province)|Sicily]], although he is known only through Seneca's writings. Regardless of how Seneca and Lucilius actually corresponded, it is clear that Seneca crafted the letters with a broad readership in mind.
The letters often begin with an observation on daily life before proceeding to an issue or principle that is abstracted from it. The result is a diary or handbook of philosophical meditations. The letters focus on many traditional themes of [[Stoicism|Stoic philosophy]] such as the contempt of death, the stout-heartedness of the sage, and virtue as the supreme good.
==Writing== The ''Letters'' were probably written in the last three years of Seneca's life. It is generally agreed that the letters are arranged in the order in which they were written.<ref name="sataioli193">{{Harvnb|Setaioli|2013|p=193}}</ref> In letter 8 Seneca alludes to his retirement from public life which is thought (by reference to Tacitus ''[[Annals (Tacitus)|Annals]]'' xiv. 52–6) to have been around spring 62.<ref name="sataioli1912">{{Harvnb|Setaioli|2013|pp=191-2}}</ref> Letter 18 was written in December in the run-up to the [[Saturnalia]]. Letter 23 refers to a cold spring, presumably in 63.<ref name="sataioli1912"/> Letter 67 refers to the end of a cold spring and is thought (in order to allow forty-three intervening letters to be written) to have been written the following year.<ref name="sataioli1912"/> Letter 91 refers to the great fire of [[Lugdunum]] (Lyon) which took place in the late summer of 64.<ref name="sataioli1912"/> Letter 122 refers to the shrinking daylight hours of autumn.<ref name="fanthamxxii">{{Harvnb|Fantham|2010|p=xxii}}</ref> Other chronologies are possible; in particular if letters 23 and 67 refer to the same spring then this can reduce the timescale by a full year.<ref name="sataioli1912"/>
The 124 letters are arranged in twenty manuscript volumes, but the collection is not complete.<ref name="sataioli198">{{Harvnb|Setaioli|2013|p=198}}</ref> [[Aulus Gellius]] (mid-2nd-century) quotes an extract from the "twenty-second book", so some letters are missing.<ref name="gravlong6">{{Harvnb|Graver|Long|2015|p=6}}</ref> However since the fire of Lyon mentioned in letter 91 took place less than a year before Seneca's death (in spring 65) the number of missing letters is not thought to be very many.<ref name="gravlong6"/>
Collectively the letters constitute Seneca's longest work.<ref name="gravlong6"/> Although addressed to Lucilius, the letters take the form of open letters,<ref name="sataioli194">{{Harvnb|Setaioli|2013|p=194}}</ref> and are clearly written with a wider readership in mind.<ref name="gravlong4">{{Harvnb|Graver|Long|2015|p=4}}</ref> The [[Epistle|epistolary genre]] was well-established in Seneca's time.<ref name="sataioli196">{{Harvnb|Setaioli|2013|p=196}}</ref> Seneca refers to Cicero's [[Epistulae ad Atticum|letters to Atticus]] and the letters of [[Epicurus]], and he was probably familiar with the [[Epistles (Plato)|letters of Plato]] and the [[Epistles (Horace)|epistles of Horace]].<ref name="sataioli195">{{Harvnb|Setaioli|2013|p=195}}</ref> However, despite the careful literary crafting, there is no obvious reason to doubt that they are real letters.<ref name="sataioli193">{{Harvnb|Setaioli|2013|p=193}}</ref> Seneca often says that he is writing in response to a letter from Lucilius, although there is unlikely to have been a strict back-and-forth exchange of letters.<ref name="fanthamxxi">{{Harvnb|Fantham|2010|p=xxi}}</ref> Even if both writers had access to the imperial mail service, a letter from central Italy to Sicily would have taken four to eight days to travel.<ref name="fanthamxxi"/> In many instances Seneca probably composed letters as a new subject occurred to him.<ref name="fanthamxxi"/> On average the letters tend to become longer over time,<ref name="sataioli198"/> and the later letters focus increasingly on theoretical questions.<ref name="sataioli192"/> However even in the later letters Seneca continues to include letters that are very short.<ref name="gravlong5"/>
==Content== [[File:Seneca - Epistolae ad Lucilium, MCCCCLXXXXIIII a di XIIII di Aprile - 544792.jpg|thumb|right|Printed edition in the Italian ([[Tuscan dialect|Tuscan]]) vernacular. 1494]] These letters all start with the phrase "''Seneca Lucilio suo salutem''" ("Seneca greets his Lucilius") and end with the word "''Vale''" ("Farewell"). In these letters, Seneca gives Lucilius advice on how to become a more devoted [[Stoicism|Stoic]]. Some of the letters include "On Noise" and "Asthma". Others include letters on "the influence of the masses" and "how to deal with one's slaves". Although they deal with Seneca's personal style of Stoic philosophy, they also give us valuable insights into daily life in ancient Rome.
There is a general tendency throughout the letters to open proceedings with an observation of a specific (and usually rather minor) incident, which then digresses to a far wider exploration of an issue or principle that is abstracted from it.<ref name="rommy"/> In one letter, for instance, Seneca begins by discussing a chance visit to an arena where a gladiatorial combat to the death is being held; Seneca then questions the morality and ethics of such a spectacle, in what is the first record (to our current knowledge) of a pre-Christian writer bringing up such a debate on that particular matter.<ref name="rommy"/>
Seneca frequently quotes Latin poets, especially [[Virgil]], but also [[Ovid]], [[Horace]], and [[Lucretius]].<ref name="gravlong89">{{Harvnb|Graver|Long|2015|pp=8-9}}</ref> Seneca also quotes [[Publilius Syrus]], such as during the eighth letter, "On the Philosopher's Seclusion".<ref>[[s:Moral letters to Lucilius/Letter 8|''Moral letters to Lucilius'', Letter 8]]</ref>
==Themes== Seneca's letters are focused on the inner-life, and the joy which comes from wisdom.<ref name="gravlong13">{{Harvnb|Graver|Long|2015|p=13}}</ref> He emphasizes the Stoic theme that virtue is the only true good and vice the only true evil.<ref name="sataioli192">{{Harvnb|Setaioli|2013|p=192}}</ref> He repeatedly refers to the brevity of life and the fleeting nature of time.<ref name="sataioli193"/>
Underlying a large number of the letters is a concern with death on the one hand (a central topic of Stoic philosophy, and one embodied in Seneca's observation that we are "dying every day") and suicide on the other, a key consideration given Seneca's deteriorating political position and the common use of forced suicide as a method of elimination of figures deemed to be oppositional to the Emperor's power and rule.<ref name="rommy">{{cite web |last1=Romm |first1=James |title=Rome's House of Cards |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/masterpiece-letters-to-lucilius-by-seneca-the-younger-a-look-at-roman-government-1394820402 |website=The Wall Street Journal|date=14 March 2014 |accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref>
Early letters often conclude with a maxim to meditate on, although this strategy is over by the thirtieth letter.<ref name="gravlong5">{{Harvnb|Graver|Long|2015|p=5}}</ref> Such maxims are typically drawn from [[Epicurus]], but Seneca regards this as a beginner's technique.<ref name="gravlong11">{{Harvnb|Graver|Long|2015|p=11}}</ref> In letter 33 he stresses that the student must begin to make well-reasoned judgements independently.<ref name="gravlong11"/>
==Language and style== [[File:Epistulaemoralesadlucilium1887paris.JPG|thumb|right|French edition, 1887]] The language and style of the letters is quite varied, and this reflects the fact that they are a mixture of private conversation and literary fiction. As an example, there is a mix of different vocabulary, incorporating technical terms (in fields such as medicine, law and navigation) as well as colloquial terms and philosophical ones.<ref name="berno">{{cite web |last1=Berno |first1=Francesca Romana |title=Epistulae Morales ad Lucilium |url=https://www.academia.edu/1125154/Seneca_Epistles |website=Academia.edu |accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref> Seneca also uses a range of devices for particular effects, such as ironic parataxis, hypotactic periods, direct speech interventions and rhetorical techniques such as alliterations, chiasmus, polyptoton, paradoxes, antitheses, oxymoron, etymological figures and so forth. In addition there are neologisms and [[hapax legomena]].<ref name="berno"/>
==Later history== The oldest manuscripts of the letters date from the ninth-century.<ref name="gravlong20">{{Harvnb|Graver|Long|2015|p=20}}</ref> For a long time the letters did not circulate together, letters 89–124 in particular appear in their own manuscripts.<ref name="gravlong20"/> They began to be widely circulated together from the twelfth-century onwards.<ref name="gravlong21">{{Harvnb|Graver|Long|2015|p=21}}</ref> The first printed edition appeared in 1475.<ref name="gravlong21"/> [[Erasmus]] produced a much superior edition in 1529.<ref name="gravlong21"/>
==Legacy and influence== [[Michel de Montaigne]] was influenced by his reading of Seneca's letters,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Clark |first1=Carol E. |title=Seneca's Letters to Lucilius as a source of some of Montaigne's imagery |journal=Bibliothèque d'Humanisme et Renaissance |date=1968 |volume=30, 2 |pages=249–266 |url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/41430068?uid=3738032&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&sid=21103904873161 |accessdate=27 June 2014}}</ref> and he modelled his ''[[Essays (Montaigne)|Essays]]'' on them.<ref name="gravlong21"/> The letters were a principal source for [[Justus Lipsius]] for the development of his [[Neostoicism]] towards the end of the 16th-century.<ref name="gravlong21"/>
==English translations== ===Complete=== There have been several full translations of the 124 letters ever since [[Thomas Lodge]] included a translation in his complete works of 1614. *Thomas Lodge (1614). ''The workes of Lucius Annæus Seneca, both morrall and naturall''. London: William Stansby *Thomas Morell (1786). ''The Epistles of Lucius Annæus Seneca''. 2 vols. London: W. Woodfall *Richard M. Gummere (1917, 1920, 1925). ''Seneca: Ad Lucilium epistulae morales''. 3 vols. Loeb Classical Library *Margaret Graver, A. A. Long (2015). ''Letters on Ethics: To Lucilius''. University of Chicago Press. {{ISBN|022652843X}}
===Selections=== There have been many selected and abridged translations of Seneca's letters. Recent editions include: *Robin Campbell (1969). ''Letters from a Stoic''. Penguin. {{ISBN|0140442103}} (40 letters) *Elaine Fantham (2010). ''Seneca. Selected Letters''. Oxford World's Classics. {{ISBN|0199533210}} (88 letters)
==Quotations== The tag ''Vita sine litteris mors'' ('Life without learning [is] death') is adapted from ''Epistle'' 82 (originally ''Otium sine litteris mors'', 'Leisure without learning [is] death') and is the [[motto]] of [[Derby School]] and [[Derby Grammar School]] in [[England]], [[Adelphi University]], [[New York (state)|New York]], and Manning's High School, [[Jamaica]].
The work is also the source for the phrase ''[[non scholae sed vitae]]'': "We do not learn for school, but for life".
==Criticism== *[[Erasmus]] in his 1529 edition raised three main criticisms of the letters. **First was Seneca's habit of mixing personas in the work, running objections and refutations of obections together in a way that Eramus found not illuminating but obfuscatory.<ref name="fanthamxxviii">{{Harvnb|Fantham|2010|p=xxviii}}</ref> **Second was the way Seneca, in complaining about philosophical logic-chopping, nevertheless filled his pages with much of that empty quibbling himself, in illustration - prompting Erasmus to second [[Quintilian]]'s objection to Seneca's own standing as a philosopher.<ref name="fanthamxxviii"/> **Thirdly, Erasmus felt that the letters were more disguised essays than a real correspondence: "one misses in Seneca that quality that lends other letters their greatest charm, that is that they are a true reflection of a real situation".<ref name="fanthamxxviii"/>

{{Refimprove|date=February 2010}} '''Hempel's dilemma''' is a question first asked (at least on record) by the philosopher [[Carl Gustav Hempel|Carl Hempel]].<ref name=Hempel>{{citation | chapter = Reduction: Ontological and linguistic facets | last1 = Hempel | first1 = Carl Gustav | title = Philosophy, Science, and Method: Essays in Honor of Ernest Nagel | editors = S. Morgenbesser, P. Suppes, and M. White | publisher = [[St. Martins Press]] | location = New York | pages = 179–199 | year = 1969 }}</ref> It has relevance to [[Metaphysical naturalism|naturalism]] and [[physicalism]] in philosophy, and to [[philosophy of mind]].
==Overview== [[Physicalism]], in at least one rough sense, is the claim that the entire world may be described and explained using the [[physical law|laws of nature]], in other words, that all phenomena are natural phenomena. This leaves open the question of what is 'natural', but one common understanding of the claim is that everything in the world is ultimately explicable in the terms of physics. This is known as reductive physicalism. However, this type of physicalism in its turn leaves open the question of what we are to consider as the proper terms of physics. There seem to be two options here, and these options form the horns of Hempel's dilemma, because neither seems satisfactory.
On the one hand, we may define the physical as whatever is currently explained by our best physical theories, e.g., [[quantum mechanics]], [[general relativity]]. Though many would find this definition unsatisfactory, some would accept that we have at least a general understanding of the physical based on these theories, and can use them to assess what is physical and what is not. And therein lies the rub, as a worked-out explanation of mentality currently lies outside the scope of such theories.
On the other hand, if we say that some future, "ideal" physics is what is meant, then the claim is rather empty, for we have no idea of what this means. The "ideal" physics may even come to define what we think of as mental as part of the physical world. In effect, physicalism by this second account becomes the circular claim that all phenomena are explicable in terms of physics because physics properly defined is whatever explains all phenomena.
[[Carlo Beenakker|Beenakker]] has proposed<ref>[https://arxiv.org/abs/physics/0702072v1 Carlo Beenakker (2007), "Hempel's dilemma and the physics of computation"]</ref> to resolve Hempel's dilemma with the definition: "The boundary between physics and metaphysics is the boundary between what can and what cannot be computed in the age of the universe".
Hempel's dilemma is relevant to philosophy of mind because explanations of issues such as [[consciousness]], [[knowledge representation|representation]], and [[intentionality]] are very hard to come by using current physics although many people in philosophy (and other fields such as [[cognitive science]], [[psychology]], and [[neuroscience]]) hold to physicalism.

|work=Shamanism.com |access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref> Shamans are often regarded as people who can connect with nature and spirits and can often also heal spiritual as well as physical sicknesses.<ref name=":2" /> Although shamanic practices have differed slightly around the world, the fundamental principles and believes remain the same, with variation occurring in rituals and worship of ancestors. Shamans are often highly respected in their communities due to the multiple roles they play.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.56thparallel.com/shamanism-in-siberia/ |title=Shamanism in Russia – Embrace the Ancient Rituals and Traditions |date=2015-06-18 |work=Tours in Russia |access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref> Shamanism is especially associated with the native peoples of [[Siberia]] in northern Asia, where shamanic practice has been noted for centuries by Asian and Western visitors,<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.rferl.org/a/shaman-of-siberia/27992537.html |title=The Shamans of Siberia |website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty |access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref> and the term itself derives from a Siberian language, though ''shamanism'' as a [[Cultural anthropology|cultural anthropological]] term is applied much more broadly to similar practices world-wide.
== Definition == [[File:Shamanism.jpg|thumb|Shamanic Ritual<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.seekeraftertruth.com/developing-shamanic-powers/ |title=Developing Shamanic Powers |work=SeekerAfterTruth.com |access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref>]]Shamanism is an ideology that used to be widely practiced in Europe, Asia, Tibet, North and South America, and Africa, centered on the belief in supernatural phenomenon such as the world of gods, demons, and ancestral spirits only responsive to a shaman.<ref>{{Cite book |url= https://books.google.com.au/books?id=3_inrj3puRQC&printsec=frontcover&dq=history+of+shamanism&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwilhtTr7qfdAhWSOnAKHf-HDRgQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=history%20of%20shamanism&f=false |title=Shamanism, History, and the State |last=Thomas |first=Nicholas |last2=Humphrey |first2=Caroline |date=1996 |publisher=University of Michigan Press |isbn=0472084011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/shamanism |title= Definition of Shamanism |website=Merriam-Webster.com |access-date=2018-09-07}}</ref> The word ''shamanism'' derives from the [[Manchu-Tungus]] word {{lang|tuw|šaman}}, meaning 'one who knows'.<ref>{{Cite book |url= http://worldcat.org/oclc/940167815 |title=Shamans: Siberian Spirituality and the Western Imagination |last=Ronald |first=Hutton |date=2011 |publisher=TPB |oclc=940167815}}</ref> Shamanism have also been defined as shamans having entered into another state of altered consciousness which can enable one to connect with spiritual beings not of the mainstream world. They have been associated as healers, teachers, scholars and a spiritual guide in the early times of human civilization.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book |url= https://books.google.com.au/books?id=imfiCgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=history+of+shamanism&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwilhtTr7qfdAhWSOnAKHf-HDRgQ6AEILjAB#v=onepage&q=history%20of%20shamanism&f=false |title=Historical Dictionary of Shamanism |last1=Harvey |first1=Graham |last2=Wallis |first2=Robert J. |date=2015 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |isbn=9781442257986}}</ref> Shamans are often highly regarded due to the multiple roles they play and is often the one who leads and guides the rituals and ceremonies that take place.
Historians such as [[:de:Hans_Findeisen|Hans Findeisen]] described it as religion because it contains a set of beliefs, tales, and ritual practices that form a well-organized net of interrelationships.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Shamanism: Critical Concepts in Sociology |last=Znamenski |first=Andrei |publisher=Routledge Curzon |date=2004 |isbn=0415311926 |location=London |pages=148}}</ref> On the other hand, there are also those such as [[Timothy Insoll]] who consider the religious label misleading because of the notion that shamanism represented a configuration within a broader religious pattern instead of religion for its followers even in [[Siberia]], the origin of the word ''shaman''.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book |title=The Origins of Shamanism, Spirit Beliefs, and Religiosity: A Cognitive Anthropological Perspective |last=Sidky |first=H. |publisher=Lexington Books |date=2017 |isbn=9781498551892 |location=Lanham, Maryland |pages=69}}</ref> This conception, according to an account,<ref name=":5" /> fits what [[Harvey Whitehouse]] described as "imagistic mode of religiosity".<ref>{{Cite book |title=Modes of Religiosity: A Cognitive Theory of Religious Transmission |last=Whitehouse |first=Harvey |publisher=Altamira Press |date=2004 |isbn=0759106142 |location=Walnut Creek, California |pages=77–78}}</ref>
== Origin == [[Shamanism]] practices varies across the globe where it is a prehistoric tradition from the [[Paleolithic era]], with cave art some 30,000 years old showing evidence of shamanic practices. The term's origin in the history of Manchu-Tungus and related languages is unknown and this is primarily attributed to the way it comes from an oral tradition.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book |title=An Encyclopedia of Shamanism |volume=1 |last=Pratt |first=Christina |publisher=Rosen Publishing Group |date=2007 |isbn=9781404210400 |location=New York |page=xxi}}</ref> Anthropologists, however, propose that it originated in northern Asia, particularly from the [[Evenki language|Evenki]] word ''saman'', which is derived from the [[Tungusic languages|Tunguso]]-[[Manchu language|Manchurian]] verb {{lang|tuw|sa}} (to know) and also related to the same word used by the [[Mongols]], and the ''kan'' and ''xam'' of [[Turkic languages]].<ref name=":6" />{{clarify|date=November 2018|reason=Which languages? Neither "kan" nor "xam" are Turkish for 'to know'.}}
There is a theory that the origin of shamanism has a physiological basis on account of the capacity of all [[mammal]]ian [[nervous system]]s for [[trance]] and altered perception.<ref>{{Cite book |title=From Shaman to Scientist: Essays on Humanity's Search for Spirits |last=Houran |first=James |publisher=Scarecrow Press |date=2004 |isbn=0810850540 |location=Lanham, Maryland |pages=22}}</ref> This drew support from the claim made by [[Jean Clottes]] and [[David Lewis-Williams]] that prehistoric humans experienced [[Hallucination|hallucinations]] and performed repetitive ritual activities that affected the consciousness,<ref>{{Cite book |title=Flights of the Soul: Visions, Heavenly Journeys, and Peak Experiences in the Biblical World |last=Pilch |first=John |publisher=William B. Eerdmans Publishing |date=2011 |isbn=9780802865403 |location=Grand Rapids, Michigan |pages=66}}</ref> to explain the emergence of shamans.
Shamanic practices have often been regarded as one of the oldest spiritual practices which have slowly become incorporated into other religions replicated through mystic and symbolic practices and rituals of other religion.<ref name=":0" /> Shamanism practices have been found all over the world however little traces of it remain as it has gradually declined in practice and as a religion. Before shamanism faded out it was one of the most widely practiced religions with practices differing in multiple regions however they are all still similar in which the religion revolves around shamans and the multiple spiritual beliefs. [[File:Witsen-Shaman.png|alt=|thumb|<ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.cuyamungueinstitute.com/monthly-newsletter/march-2016/witsen-shaman/ |title=Witsen Shaman |work=Cuyamungue Institute Monthly Newsletter |publisher=[[Cuyamungue Institute]] |access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref>An illustration of a Shaman in Siberia in the 17th century by Nicolaes Witsen.]]
== Historical background ==
Shamanism varies from region to region, country to country as a result of differing cultures and beliefs. As shamanism has been around for so long the exact date of when shamanism actually occurred leaves much to be debated by anthropologists, due to issues with historical preservation and historical accuracy of records. Shamanism is believed to have been around as early as the Paleolithic era or more commonly known as the Stone Age.<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080430093540/http://www.bradshawfoundation.com/clottes/page7.php |title=Paleolithic Cave Paintings and Rock Art in France |work=BradshawFoundation.com |publisher=[[Bradshaw Foundation]] |date=2008-04-30 |access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref>In Europe and Africa cave artworks from the Paleolithic era dated some 20,000 years ago indicate that shamanic practices were prominent even during that time.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book |title=The Spirit of Shamanism |last=Walsh |first=Roger N. |publisher=Tarcher Perigree |date=1991 |isbn=0874776260 |pages=}}</ref> Due to shamanism practices varying across each continent and country there is also a discrepancy in its history however as not enough history was preserved to explain in great detail due to the decline of shamanism as well as various other historical events.
Although there is evidence suggesting that shamanism has been around for 30,000 years and maybe even longer there is however no solid evidence which provides conclusive evidence as to the exact time period on when shamanism has come about.<ref name=":3" /> There is however concrete evidence that shamanism has existed for at least 10,000 years ago due to excavations Shamans often play an important role in each tribal society and are often regarded as the healer and also the medium that can communicate with spirits and the dead where they are often responsible for sacrificial rituals where ceremonies are carried out by them and throughout history they were a vital part of each tribe.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.illinoisstatemuseum.org/content/online-resources |title=Online Resources {{!}} Illinois State Museum |work=IllinoisStateMuseum.org |access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> However, Shamanism has slowly started to decline as time progressed and new religions such as Christianity came in and eventually only a few remote tribes still retained the practices of shamanism and one such tribe is the Inuit Tribe in the Canadian Arctic.<ref>{{Cite journal |first1=Jarich |last1=Oosten |first2=Frédéric |last2=Laugrand |first3=Cornelius |last3=Remie |date=Summer 2006 |title=Perceptions of Decline: Inuit Shamanism in the Canadian Arctic |url= https://doi.org/10.1215/00141801-2006-001 |journal=Ethnohistory |volume=53 |issue=3 |pages=445-447}}</ref> Traditional shamanism often involved the Shamans being chosen by the tribe or inherited however as the tradition of Shamanism declined and now replaced with a modern version of Shamanism people can now choose to take up shamanism training.<ref name="Scuro & Rodd" /> Traditionally the role of shamans is one that is often respected and regarded as an elder in the tribe. [[File:Star_Carr.jpg|alt=|thumb|Image of the Excavation site Star Carr located in North Yorkshire England. The image is a reconstruction Alan Sorrell's reconstruction of Star Carr in 1951, Illustrated London News 3 <ref name=":7" />]] In a excavation of a Mesolithic archaeological site, Star Carr located in North Yorkshire, [[England]], evidence of shamanism can be found in the archaeological findings.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web |url= https://guerillaarchaeology.wordpress.com/resources/mesolithic-shamanism/ |title=Mesolithic Shamanism? |date=2012-06-08 |work=Guerilla Archaeology |access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> The Mesolithic period or otherwise known as the Middle Stone Age dates between 10,000 BC and 4000 BC.<ref name=":7" /><ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.britannica.com/event/Mesolithic-Period |title=Mesolithic Period {{!}} prehistoric period |work=Encyclopaedia Britannica |access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> At the Star Carr excavation site they found twenty one adult red deer skull parts where there was evidence that these skull parts was deliberately carved and shaped to make it possible for them to be worn on the head of humans with archaeologists suggesting these were used on special occasions or for shamanic practices.<ref name=":7" /> This was suggested due to the fact that a characteristic part of shamanic rituals was the headdress's seen on shamans as part of the ceremonial costume where is was believed that headdresses had the effect of increasing concentration in shamans when they are in meditation or performing spiritual ceremonies.<ref name=":7" /> To this day Star Carr plays a vital role in understanding the history of shamanism especially from a western point of view due to limited historical records as they have not been able to be preserved throughout time.
Not only in England but costume has played a key role in shamanic practices as it is believed to allow one to better integrate themselves with the spiritual world and the nature around them with many archaeologists suggesting that during the middle stone age period natural places like hills, waterfalls and caves contain animistic entities.<ref name=":7" /> This is particularly so as shamanic practices have traditionally been correlated to the naturalistic world.
Even though it has declined, Shamanism has managed to survive the prosecution of various regimes through time such as other organised religion and Marxist regimes with key principles of Shamanism still present today albeit limited in many areas.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Balzar |first=M. M. |chapter=Legacies of Fear: Religious Repression and Resilience in Siberia |editor1-first=S. |editor1-last=Krippner |editor2-first=T. M. |editor2-last=McIntyre |title=The Psychological Impact of War Trauma on Civilians: An International Perspective |publisher=Praeger |date=2003 |isbn=|location=Wesport, Connecticut |pages=256–267}}</ref> One of the last practices of Shamanism in the 21st Century can be found in nomadic Tuvan tribe with only an estimated 3000 people surviving from this tribe.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news |url= https://www.lonelyplanet.com/mongolia/travel-tips-and-articles/mongolias-lost-secrets-in-pictures-the-last-tuvan-shaman/40625c8c-8a11-5710-a052-1479d2767e50 |title=Mongolia's Lost Secrets in Pictures: The Last Tuvan Shaman |date=2014-08-21 |work=Lonely Planet |access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref> Tuva is one of the most isolated tribes in Russia where the art of shamanism been preserved until today due to its isolated existence, allowing it to be free from the influences of other major religions.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://thediplomat.com/2016/10/welcome-to-the-tuva-republic/ |title=Welcome to the Tuva Republic |first1=Bradley |last1=Jardine |first2=Matthew |last2=Kupfer |work=The Diplomat |access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref> The Khakas is another tribe isolated from the world where living in the Steppes of Southern Siberia where there history dates back to the Copper age with cave art as proof with shamanism still being prominent in the present age.<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.rbth.com/longreads/shamans/ |title=Revelations of a Siberian Shaman |work=Russia Beyond |publisher=TV-Novosti |location=Moscow |access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref>
== In the modern world == Shamanism has long declined and this is because larger religions have emerged and replacing it. Shamanism has declined mainly due to larger religions coming in and replacing it where shamanism is now often considered as a primitive and superstitious religion which is untrue.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Oosten |first=J. |date=2006-07-01 |title=Perceptions of Decline: Inuit Shamanism in the Canadian Arctic |url= https://doi.org/10.1215/00141801-2006-001 |journal=Ethnohistory |volume=53 |issue=3 |pages=445–477 |doi=10.1215/00141801-2006-001|issn=0014-1801}}</ref> Shamanism is a religion that has changed over time and modern shamanism in the Western context is now regarded as [[neo-shamanism]], which emerged in the 20th century. It involves the integration of traditional indigenous shamanic techniques combined with psychotherapeutic techniques of the urbanised Western world where its main inspiration is derived mainly from the indigenous shamanic practices of Amazonian, Mesoamerican, and North American indigenous people.<ref name="Scuro & Rodd">{{cite journal |last1=Scuro |first1=Juan |last2=Rodd |first2=Robin |title=Neo-Shamanism |date=2015-01-01 |url= https://www.researchgate.net/publication/304036146_Neo-Shamanism |pages=1–6 |access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref> Michael Harner introduced the concept of "core shamanism" in his work ''The Way of the Shaman'', which forms the basis of neo-shamanism.<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.huffpost.com/entry/neoshamanism_b_976102 |title=Neoshamanism: A Call to the Western Animistic Soul |work=[[Huffington Post]] |access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref>
[[File:Neoshamanism.jpg|alt=|thumb|A reflection on neo-shamanism in the form of art – aims to communicate the adventures of the soul, physically and spiritually.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://balkanvagabondz.com/2017/01/16/introduction-to-the-art-of-neo-shamanism/ |title=Introduction to the Art of Neo-Shamanism |date=2017-01-16 |work=BalkanVagabondz.com |access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref>]] Today, shamanism is considered a universal religion something that transcends geographical and cultural boundaries with emphasis on the importance in reconnecting with our spiritual roots.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Shamanism: Archaic Techniques of Ecstasy |last=Eliade |first=Mircea |publisher=FCE |date=2009 |isbn= |location=Mexico |pages=}}</ref> With the rise of the counterculture movement where people started to seek to understand more on ones consciousness, spiritual connection and healing, people began to look into the historical roots of shamanism and a growing interest in plant-based hallucinogenic drugs. This gave rise to neo-shamanism in that time period where it started to gain a greater prominence and interest globally. The counterculture movement was a time during the 1960s where youth rejected the socials norms of that era with a rise in women rights, LGBT movement and experiments with psychedelic music and drugs.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.worldatlas.com/articles/what-was-the-counterculture-of-the-1960s-and-70s.html |title=What Was the Counterculture of the 1960s and 1970s? |work=WorldAtlas |access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref> This led to a rise in neo-shamanism due to what it embodies about spiritual consciousness and psychotherapy. Neo-shamanism often dismisses the evil and fear that has been associated with traditional shamanism where fear and evil was a core part of shamanic rituals in some spiritual connections.<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120120013711/http://www.ull.es/congresos/conmirel/YORK.html |title=The Role of Fear in Traditional and Contemporary Shamanism |work=ULL.es |date=2012-01-20 |access-date=2018-10-05}}</ref>
Beginning in the 20th century, people began to see shamanism as a form of psychotherapy suggesting that shamanic practices is comparable to that of psychoanalysis.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Levi-Strauss |first=Claude |chapter=The Effectiveness of Symbols |translator1-last=Jacobsen |translator1-first=C. |translator2-last=Schoepf |translator2-first=B. G. |title=Structuralanthropology |publisher=Basic Books |date=1963 |ISBN= |location=New York |pages=186-205}}</ref> For instance, [[Abraham Maslow]] referred to shamanism as an ancient form of psychotherapy, particularly one that supports the view of psychotherapy as need gratification through interpersonal relations.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Genealogies of Shamanism: Struggles for Power, Charisma and Authority |last=Boekhoven |first=Jeroen |publisher=Barkhuis |date=2011 |isbn=9789077922927 |location=Groningen |pages=178}}</ref> Thereafter, shamanism practices have been increasingly studied by medical specialists and psychologists who utilize its core principles to better complement the treatments given.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.naturalawakeningsmag.com/Healing-Ways-Archive/The-Modern-Shaman/ |title=The Modern Shaman |access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref>
Psychologists have also done numerous research on the core principles of shamanism and applying it to spiritual and mental well being by using it in psychological treatments. Much research has gone into looking at how spiritualism can help with easing of the mind playing a bigger role in psychology today. Modern shamanism can also be explained in a scientific sense as one that is inherently able to connect with our beliefs on a spiritual level in a certain state of consciousness. <ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.sharedwisdom.com/article/modern-shaman |title=The Modern Shaman |work=SharedWisdom.com |access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> This is demonstrated in the case of the shamanic journey where the shaman enters an alternate state of consciousness and acquire knowledge through access to multiple layers of reality.<ref name=":10">{{Cite book |url= https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=t1koDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT88&dq=shaman+journey+consciousness&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3i8_mpufeAhWDMnwKHVR6DNIQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=shaman%20journey%20consciousness&f=false |title=The Shamanic Path to Quantum Consciousness: The Eight Circuits of Creative Power |last=Huguelit |first=Laurent |date=2013-12-17 |publisher=Simon and Schuster |isbn=9781591438489}}</ref> This has been considered a psychological technique that has certain similarities to [[Lucid dream|lucid dreams]], [[Analytical psychology|Jungian]] active imagination, and [[Near-death experience|near-death experiences]].<ref>{{Cite book |title=The Corsini Encyclopedia of Psychology |volume=4 |last1=Weiner |first1=Irving |last2=Craighead |first2=Edward |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |date=2010 |isbn=9780470170243 |location=Hoboken, New Jersey |pages=1586}}</ref> When applied as a treatment, the shamanic journey allows the retrieval of memory and the causes of problems such as trauma.<ref name=":10" />
As shamanic beliefs embraces cosmogenic beliefs from a scientific view researchers have considered the idea that various aspects of shamanic trance like healing is involved with activating certain areas of the brain to generate certain somatic reactions.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal |last1=Albert |first1=J.-P. |last2=Crubézy |first2=E. |date=2005 |title=Shamanic healing in the age of modern medicine |url= https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15903086 |journal=Medecine Tropicale: Revue du Corps de Sante Colonial |volume=65 |issue=1 |pages=93–99 |issn=0025-682X |pmid=15903086}}</ref> Looking from this aspect it has meant that doctors and psychologists are placing greater importance in the resurgence of certain shamanic practices as it can potentially have large benefits in therapeutic management of social and psychoaffective factors.<ref name=":9" />

{{italic title}} '''''Homo unius libri''''' ("(a) man of one book") is a [[Latin language|Latin]] phrase attributed to [[Thomas Aquinas]] in a literary tradition going back to at least the 17th century, bishop [[Jeremy Taylor]] (1613–1667) being the earliest known writer in English to have done so. Saint Thomas Aquinas is reputed to have employed the phrase "''hominem unius libri [[wikt:en:timeo#Latin|timeo]]''" (meaning "I fear the man of a single book").
There are other attributions, and variants of the phrase. Variants include ''cave'' for ''timeo'', and ''virum'' or ''lectorem'' ("reader") for ''hominem''. ''The Concise Dictionary of Foreign Quotations'' (London 1998), attributes the quote to [[Augustine of Hippo]]. Other attributions named [[Pliny the Younger]], [[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]], [[Quintilian]] or [[Augustine]], but the existence of the phrase cannot be substantiated as predating the [[early modern period]].<ref> Andreas Fritsch, "Timeo lectorem unius libri", '' Vox Latina'' 19 (1983), 309 ff. Pliny did express a comparable sentiment. "''CAVE AB HOMINE UNIUS LIBRI.'' Never was this old Latin proverb of greater import, never did it convey a deeper meaning than in this, our own century, when everyone appears to have become an "heluo librorum." Since most men seem to know a little of everything and not much of anything, the man of one book, the reader who is intimate with one great author, whom he has chosen for his favorite, who has imbibed the spirit of his model, and fashioned almost insensibly his own mind after that of his exemplar, is, indeed, a formidable antagonist. Pliny tells us that we should read much, but not many books." ''The Stylus'', Volume III, Number 3, 1 April 1885. [http://newspapers.bc.edu/cgi-bin/bostonsh?a=d&d=stylus18850401-01.2.8 newspapers.bc.edu]</ref>
The phrase was in origin a dismissal of [[eclecticism]], i.e. the "fear" is of the formidable intellectual opponent who has dedicated himself to and become a master in a single chosen discipline; however, the phrase today most often refers to the interpretation of expressing "fear" of the opinions of the [[illiterate]] man who has "only read a single book".<ref>In ''The Portable Twentieth-Century Russian Reader'', Clarence Brown, editor (Penguin) 1985, p. 246; see ''[[The Hedgehog and the Fox]]'' for further discussion of this phrase.</ref>
==Interpretations==
===Mastery of a single topic=== The literary critic Clarence Brown described the phrase in his introduction to a novel by [[Yuri Olesha]]: {{quote|[Aquinas's] words are generally quoted today in disparagement of the man whose mental horizons are limited to one book. Aquinas, however, meant that a man who has thoroughly mastered one good book can be dangerous as an opponent. The Greek poet [[Archilochus]] meant something like this when he said that the [[fox]] knows many things but the [[hedgehog]] knows one big thing.<ref>In ''The Portable Twentieth-Century Russian Reader'', Clarence Brown, e ditor (Penguin) 1985, p. 246; see ''[[The Hedgehog and the Fox]]'' for further discussion of this phrase.</ref>}}
The poet [[Robert Southey]] recalled the tradition in which the quotation became embedded: {{quote|When St Thomas Aquinas was asked in what manner a man might best become learned, he answered, 'By reading one book'; 'meaning,' says [[Jeremy Taylor|Bishop Taylor]], 'that an understanding entertained with several objects is intent upon neither, and profits not.<ref>Jeremy Taylor, ''Life of Christ'', Pt. II. Sect. II. Disc. II. 16.</ref> The ''homo unius libri'' is indeed proverbially formidable to all conversational figurantes. Like your sharp-shooter, he knows his piece perfectly, and is sure of his shot.<ref>[http://digicoll.library.wisc.edu/cgi-bin/Literature/Literature-idx?type=div&did=LITERATURE.0006.0185.0104&isize=text&pview=hide Robert Southey, ''The Doctor, &c'', (1848), Interchapter VII (e-text)]. Southey's version of the quote was taken up by [[John Bartlett (publisher)|John Bartlett]] (1820-1905), the compiler of ''[[Bartlett's Familiar Quotations]]'' (ninth edition, 1902, p. 853).</ref>}}
By way of comparison, Southey quotes [[Lope de Vega]]'s ''Isidro de Madrid'' expressing a similar sentiment, :''For a noteworthy student is he, :''The man of a single book. :''For when they were not filled up :''With so many extraneous books,''
The writer and naturalist [[Charles Kingsley]], following the tradition laid down by [[Gilbert White]] in ''The Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne'' (1789), also invoked the proverb in favour of knowing completely one small area. "A lesson is never learnt till it is learnt over many times, and a spot is best understood by staying in it and mastering it. In natural history the old scholar's saw ''Cave hominem unius libri''<ref>"Beware the man of one book."</ref> may be paraphrased by, 'He is a thoroughly good naturalist who knows one parish thoroughly.'"<ref>Charles Kingsley, ''At Last: A Christmas in the West Indies'', 1871.</ref>
[[John Wesley]] invoked the phrase in this sense and declared himself to be a "homo unius libri", the "one book" being the [[sola scriptura|Bible]].<ref>"in 1730 I began to be homo unius libri, to study (comparatively) no book but the Bible." Letter to John Newton, May 14, 1765. He wrote privately on another occasion :"I receive the written word as the whole and sole rule of my faith..... From the very beginning, from the time that four young men united together, each of them was homo unius libri... They had one, and only one, rule of judgement with which to regard all their tempers, words and actions; namely, the oracles of God." Wesley used it more publicly in the ''Preface'' to his collected sermons; :"He came from heaven; He hath written it down in a book. O give me that Book! At any price, give me the Book of God. I have it; here is knowledge enough for me. Let me be homo unius libri!" </ref> Like Methodists in the strict Wesleyan tradition of depending upon the One Book, many seventeenth century and modern radical Protestants pride themselves on being ''homines unius libri''. The poet [[William Collins (poet)|William Collins]] in his deranged condition, met by chance his old friend [[Dr. Samuel Johnson]], who found Collins carrying a New Testament. "I have but one book," said Collins, "but it is the best".<ref>Collins' epitaph in [[Chichester Cathedral]] reads, in part: ''Sought on one book his troubled mind to rest, And wisely deemed the book of God the best.''The Johnson anecdote and Collins' epitaph are reported in Walsh 1892 ''s.v.'', "Book, Beware of the man of one".</ref>
===Narrow learning=== [[Edward Everett]] applied the remark "not only to the man of one book, but also to the man of one idea, in whom the sense of proportion is lacking, and who sees only that for which he looks".<ref>Reported in William Shepard Walsh, ''Handy-book of Literary Curiosities'', 1892, ''s.v.'', "Book, Beware of the man of one".
<!--The familiar thought was paralleled by the Augustan poet [[Alexander Pope]]:
:A little learning is a dang'rous thing; :Drink deep, or taste not the [[Pierian Spring|Pierian spring]]: :There shallow draughts intoxicate the brain, :And drinking largely sobers us again. — ''Essay on Criticism,'' Part ii.15.--> </ref>
[[Joseph Needham]], in the general conclusions to his ''[[Science and Civilisation in China]]'' series, observed of the saying, "It could mean that this man has only read one book, has only written one book, does not possess more than one book, or puts his faith in one book only. The fear that is felt may be on behalf of the man himself. Having read so little he is quite at the mercy of his one book!"<ref>''Science and Civilisation in China'', "50 General Conclusions and Reflections", p. 97.</ref>
===Limited success as an author=== In [[Samuel Butler (novelist)|Samuel Butler]]'s ''[[The Way of All Flesh]]'' (1903), a publisher uses the phrase to describe the novel's protagonist.<ref>Ernest Pontifex, who is a writer with only one commercially or critically successful work: "'Mr Pontifex,' he said, 'is a ''homo unius libri'', but it doesn't do to tell him so.'" {{cite book|last=Butler|first=Samuel|title=The Way of All Flesh|year=1917|publisher=E.P. Dutton & Company|pages=463}}</ref> Butler also records that his own publisher, ''Trübner'', applied the phrase to him to express doubts in his literary prospect, the "one book" of Butler's in this case being ''[[Erewhon]]''.<ref> ''The Note-books of Samuel Butler'', ed. H. F. Jones (1912), [http://www.gutenberg.org/files/6173/6173-h/6173-h.htm#page155 p. 155] </ref>

{{Infobox religious biography |background = #FFD068 | color = black |name = Hongzhi Zhengjue
{{linktext|宏|智|正|覺}} |image = Tiantong_Hongzhi_Zhengjue_Zen.jpg |caption = |birth name = |alias = |dharma name = |birth_date = 1091 |birth_place = [[Shanxi|Xizhoue]], [[China]] |death_date = 1157 |death_place = |nationality = |religion = [[Chinese Chán|Chan]] |school = |lineage = |title = [[Chan master]] |location = |education = |occupation = |teacher = [[Danxia Zichun]] |reincarnation of = |predecessor = [[Danxia Zichun]] |successor = |students = |spouse = |partner = |children = |website = }} {{ZenBuddhism}} '''Hongzhi Zhengjue''' ({{zh|c=宏智正覺|p=Hóngzhì Zhēngjué|w=Hung-chih Cheng-chueh}}, {{CJKV|j=Wanshi Shōgaku}}), also sometimes called '''Tiantong Zhengjue''' ({{zh|s=天童正覺|}}; {{CJKV|j=Tendo Shōgaku}}) (1091–1157),[http://www.thezensite.com/ZenEssays/HistoricalZen/Bright_Field_of_Spirit_Hongzhi.html The Bright Field of Spirit: The Life and Teachings of Chan Master Hongzhi Zhengjue][http://www.ancientdragon.org/dharma/articles/the_art_of_just_sitting Hongzhi, Dogen and the Background of Shikantaza] was an important Chinese [[Chan Buddhism|Chan]] [[Buddhist]] monk who authored or compiled several influential texts. Hongzhi's conception of ''silent illumination'' is of particular importance to the Chinese [[Caodong school|Caodong]] Chan and Japanese [[Sōtō]] Zen schools. Hongzhi was also the author of the ''[[Book of Equanimity]]'', an important collection of [[koan|''kōan'']]s ==Life== According to the account given in [[Taigen Dan Leighton|Taigen Dan Leighton's]] ''Cultivating the Empty Field'', Hongzhi was born to a family named Li in [[Xi County, Shanxi|Xizhou]], present-day [[Shanxi]] province. He left home at the age of eleven to become a monk, studying under Caodong master [[Kumu Faqeng]], among others, including [[Yuanwu Keqin]], author of the famous ''kōan'' collection, the ''[[Blue Cliff Record]]''. In 1129, Hongzhi began teaching at the Jingde monastery on [[Mount Tiantong]], where he remained for nearly thirty years, until shortly before his death in 1157, when he ventured down the mountain to bid farewell to his supporters. ==Texts== The main text associated with Hongzhi is a collection of one hundred of his kōans called the ''[[Book of Equanimity]]'' ({{CJKV|c=從容録|p=Cóngróng Lù|j=従容録|r=Shōyōroku|}}). This book was compiled after his death by [[Wansong Xingxiu]] (1166–1246) at the urging of the [[Khitan people|Khitan]] statesman [[Yelü Chucai]] (1190–1244), and first published in 1224, with commentaries by Wansong. This book is regarded as one of the key texts of the [[Caodong school]] of Zen Buddhism.{{Cite book | last1=Buswell Jr. | first1=Robert E. | last2=Lopez Jr. | first2=Donald S. | title=The Princeton Dictionary of Buddhism | publisher=Princeton University Press | year=2013 | isbn=9781400848058 | page=197 }} A collection of Hongzhi's philosophical texts has also been translated by Leighton. Hongzhi is often referred to as an exponent of Silent Illumination Chan ({{nihongo|''Mokushō Zen'' 黙照禅|}} in Japanese). Aside from his own teacher, [[Eihei Dōgen]]—the founder of the Sōtō school of Zen in Japan—quotes Hongzhi in his work more than any other Zen figure.{{citation|title=Zen Masters|last=Heine|first=Steven|editor-last=Heine|editor-first=Steven|editor2-last=Wright|editor2-first=Dale S.|publisher=Oxford University Press|ISBN=9780195367652|page=119|contribution=Dōgen, Zen Master, Zen Disciple: Transmitter or Transgressor}} ==Sources== *''Cultivating the Empty Field: The Silent Illumination of Zen Master Hongzhi''.
